Graphical abstract Coke evolution on a Y-zeolite based catalyst and its influence on the active site and catalytic activity during catalytic pyrolysis of polyethylene for fuel oil were investigated. Results show that the coke evolution includes both quantity accumulation and structural condensation. The coke amounts increase from 0.8% at TOS = 1 h to 2.4% and 6.3% at TOS = 2 h and 4 h respectively, and the external coke deposits faster than the internal coke. Structural condensation is evidenced by DTG, H/C, 13C NMR, FTIR and UV-Vis results. The average coke model changes from a tricyclic aromatic to a hexacyclic alkyl aromatic as TOS increases from 1 h to 4 h. Coke evolution causes catalyst deactivation, resulting in the decrease of oil yields but increase of wax yields and heavy oil concentration. The strong acid sites and micropores favor the coke deposition, and fast external deposition leads to slow decrease of acidities with coke yields. Keywords Waste plastics Y zeolite Coke Pyrolysis Oil 1 Introduction The recycling of waste plastics has been a global challenge since the generation of plastic products are growing rapidly each year in both developed and developing countries [1–3]. Among the several methods for large-scale treatment of waste plastics, pyrolysis is an effective and simple approach to recover the valuable chemicals such as oil [4–6]. To obtain a high-value oil, catalysts should be used in the pyrolysis process. The commonly used catalysts are the zeolites. However, the heavy carbonaceous compounds, i.e. coke, are easily deposited on the acid site of the zeolites, resulting in the deactivation of the catalysts [7,8]. Extensive researches have been carried out to understand the coke formation mechanism and its effects on catalyst deactivation by the analytical techniques such as temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) [9,10], solid state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy [11,12] Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy [11,13], Raman spectroscopy [12,14], ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy [15,16,17], etc. With these methods, it is found that the coke formation on zeolite involves a series of elementary reactions, such as oligomerization, cyclization, hydrogen transfer, and alkylation, in which the alkenes and oligomers are considered as the intermediates and aromatics as coke precursors [18–22]. The catalyst deactivation caused by coke formation is mainly due to the acid-site poisoning as well as the pore blockage caused by the formation of heavy aromatic clusters [23–26]. In the catalytic pyrolysis of waste plastics, the coking behaviors are strongly influenced by the catalyst properties such as shape selectivity and acidity [26–29]. Among the several commonly used zeolites, the HZSM-5 shows a good ability against coke formation due to its severe shape selectivity, which sterically inhibits coke precursor evolution towards polyaromatic structures [30,31]; the Y zeolite (HY or HUSY) favor the selective production of the liquid fraction, but its large pore size and specified cages promote the coke condensation and cause a fast deactivation [12,32,33]. The coke species on these zeolites are different. Castaño et al. discovered that in the catalytic pyrolysis of polyethylene (PE), the HY coke has 4-7 aromatic rings with few aliphatic chains; the HZSM-5 coke contains one benzene ring with several aliphatic chains; and the Hβ coke contains 3-4 aromatic rings with double-bonded aliphatic chains [12]. Other factors such as operating temperature [26], feedstock properties [34,35], reactors [27,36] and volatile reactions [37] also have an influence on the coking behaviors as well as the product distributions. The continuous feeding is always a requirement in waste plastic pyrolysis. During the continuous reactions, the coke on catalyst is not invariable but evolves with time on stream (TOS). Wang and Manos investigated the evolution of coke over a USHY zeolite used in the pyrolysis of 1-pentene at 250-350 °C [38]. With the increase of TOS, the contents of coke and small coke precursors increase while that of large coke precursors decrease. Lee et al. attributed the coke evolution to the variation of internal and external coke amount but not their chemical structures [39]. They and some other researches [23,24,40] found that the internal coke formed on the zeolites consists of mainly small aromatic species, while the external coke contains more bulky polyaromatics due to the continuous condensation of aromatic molecules without the constraint of the pores. However, this finding may be dependent on the feedstock, because some researchers discovered that in the pyrolysis of polyolefins the internal coke is more condensed with a lower H/C ratio while the external coke is less developed with more aliphatic groups [28,41]. To better understand the catalyst deactivation behaviors in the continuous waste plastic-to-oil process, in this work we investigated the coke evolution on a commercial Y-zeolite based catalyst and its influence on the active site and catalytic activity in the catalytic pyrolysis of polyethylene - the main component in waste plastics - for fuel oil. Techniques including TPO, 13C NMR, FTIR, UV-Vis were used to determine the coke evolution in quantity and structure. The catalytic activity was determined by the analysis of product distribution, and the properties of the coked catalysts were characterized by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. The experimental results discovered in this work will be useful for the understanding of deactivation process and regeneration of deactivated catalysts in waste plastic treatment. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The PE pellets were provided by Shanghai Runwen Packaging Materials Co., Ltd. The spherical pellets have a diameter of 3 mm and a density of 0.92 g/cm3. A cylindrical Y-zeolite based catalyst was provided by Eco Environmental Technology Co., Ltd. It consists of 30% HY zeolite (Si/Al = 8.0) and 70% mixtures of bentonite and α-Al2O3. The catalyst has a BET surface area of 277 m2/g, an average pore diameter of 36 Å and a total acidity of 1.50 mmol NH3/g. Its N2 sorption isotherm and X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern are shown in Fig. S1. The catalyst was dried in an oven at 110 °C to remove moisture before use. The dichloromethane (≥99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as the solvent to dissolve the condensable products. The 2,6-Diisopropylnaphthalene (≥99%, Sigma-Aldrich) was used for calibration in the approximately quantitative 13C NMR analysis. 2.2 Catalytic pyrolysis experiments The catalytic pyrolysis was carried out in a vertical quartz tube (ϕ28 × 600 mm). The tube was heated by a two-stage electric furnace, in which the first stage is for the pyrolysis of PE and the second is for the catalytic cracking of the nascent volatiles generated from the PE pyrolysis. The temperature of each stage could be separately controlled. The cold traps included a condenser, a round-bottomed flask and a scrubbing bottle cooled by the iced water to collect the condensable products. The whole experimental system is shown in Fig. 1 . In each experiment, 4 g catalyst was loaded in the quartz tube. The tube was then placed into the furnace and purged with N2 in a flow rate of 400 ml/min for at least 30 min to remove the oxygen inside. The pyrolysis and catalysis stages were then heated to 500 and 450 °C respectively, which are the common temperatures for oil production [27]. When the desired temperatures were reached, a quartz basket loaded with 2 g PE pellets was hanged into the middle of the pyrolysis stage as shown in Fig. 1. The time for PE consumption in each basket is 1 h. After one basket of PE was consumed, the empty basket was removed out of the tube and replaced by another PE-loaded (2 g) basket immediately. This experimental operation was to simulate the continuous feeding in the catalytic pyrolysis of waste plastics and investigate the influence of TOS on catalyst deactivation. With this method, the catalytic pyrolysis at TOS = 1 h, 2 h and 4 h were conducted as shown in Fig. 1. After each pyrolysis experiment, the condensable products including solid wax and liquid oil were separately weighed and then dissolved by 50 ml dichloromethane for analysis. The coked catalysts were obtained for characterization after being cooled down to room temperature in N2 atmosphere. The coke yields were measured by TPO method. It should be noted that there are two bases in the coke yield calculation - one is for the catalyst mass and another is for the PE mass, as indicated in Eq. (1) and (2) respectively. The former is to show the absolute coke amount and the latter is to evaluate the catalyst activity in pyrolysis. The catalyst mass (mcatalyst ) is 4 g while the PE mass (mPE ) is dependent on the TOS - 2 g, 4 g and 8 g at TOS = 1 h, 2 h and 4 h respectively. The oil and wax yields are all based on the PE mass and the gas yield was calculated by the mass balance. At least three repeat experiments were made at each condition and the experimental errors were illustrated in the figures. (1) Coke yield ( catalyst base ) = m c o k e m c a t a l y s t × 100 % (2) Coke yield ( PE base ) = m c o k e m P E × 100 % 2.3 Analytical methods 2.3.1 Analysis of the condensable products The dissolved condensable products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (TRACE 1300, Thermo Scientific, U.S.A.) equipped with a TG-5MS capillary column (60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm, 5% phenyl methyl-polysiloxane stationary phase). Helium was used as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. The oven temperature was initially held at 50 °C for 15 min and then ramped up to 330 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min and held for 10 min. The temperature program allowed the hydrocarbons up to C45 to be detected. The mass range of the detectable products was from 1 to 1100 amu for the ion trap detector. Each compound of the products was identified based on the national institute of standards and technology (NIST) library data, and its composition was calculated according to its normalized peak area. The weight percentage of each compound was approximately equal to its area percentage. 2.3.2 Analysis of coke amount and species on catalyst The amount of coke on catalyst was quantified by TPO method using a thermobalance (SDT Q600, TA Instruments, U.S.A.). Approximately 15 mg of catalyst sample was firstly treated under an air flow rate of 50 ml/min at 200 °C for 30 min, followed by a temperature increase up to 550 °C at a heating ramp of 5 °C/min and then maintained for 10 min. No coke but only moisture on the catalyst was removed at 200 °C. The H/C ratio of the coke was determined by combustion analysis (elemental analysis) at 550 °C. The solid-state 13C cross-polarization magic-angle spinning (CP-MAS) NMR were performed at room temperature in an Agilent 600 DD2 spectrometer with a resonance frequency of 150.72 MHz, a MAS rotation speed of 10 kHz, a contact time of 1 ms, and a recycle delay time of 0.5-1.5 s. The powder samples were placed in a pencil-type zirconia rotor of 4.0 mm o.d. and analyzed for 24 h. The C signal of tetramethylsilane at 0 ppm was used as the reference of 13C chemical shift. The carbon species determined by 13C NMR were distinguished with the multi Gaussian peaks fitting, but the deconvoluted peak area cannot be directly used for quantification. To make an approximate quantitative analysis, the mixture of 5% 2,6-Diisopropylnaphthalene + 95% catalyst (similar to the coke structure and amount on catalyst) was used as the model compound. Its NMR spectrum is shown in Fig. S2. With the calibration of the model compound, the concentration of each carbon species was approximately analyzed. Detailed calibration methods were described in the supporting information. The UV-Vis spectroscopy analysis was performed at the wavelength of 200-800 nm with a resolution of 1 nm in a Hitachi U-3900H. A tungsten lamp was used for illumination and the BaSO4 powder was used as the substrate. The light reflected from the sample or the substrate was then reflected by a cylindrical wall of the integrating sphere, and finally detected by a photomultiplier placed at the center of the sphere. The FTIR spectroscopy (iS5, Thermo Nicolet, Swiss) was employed to characterize the functional structure of the coked catalysts. The catalyst samples were dried in an oven at 110 °C for 4 h to remove the moisture, then grounded into powder less than 200 mesh. After then, the catalyst power (1 mg) was mixed with the grounded KBr power (100 mg, spectral purity, less than 200 mesh) and pressed into thin wafers under a pressure of 10 MPa for 5 min. The wavenumber scan range was 400-4000 cm-1 with a resolution of 0.1 cm-1. 2.3.3 Analysis of the surface acidity The acidities of the fresh and coked catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD (AutoChem II 2920, U.S.A.). The sample (120 mg) was firstly heated to 300 °C at a He flow rate of 30 ml/min and maintained for 2 h to remove the moisture, then cooled down to 50 °C before NH3 adsorption. The cooled catalyst sample was then saturated at 50 °C in a 5% NH3/He stream with a flow rate of 50 ml/min for 1 h, followed by the He purge for 1 h to remove the weak NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface, and finally heated to 450 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min and maintained for 30 min. The NH3 signal was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector. 2.3.4 Analysis of surface area and pores The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst were measured by physical adsorption of N2 using Micromeritics ASAP-2400. The sample (200 mg) was loaded in a tube and heated to 280 °C under vacuum environment for 2 h. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, the N2 adsorption and desorption experiments were conducted at −196 °C. Specific surface area was obtained by the conventional BET method [42]. The total pore volume (Vt ) was calculated from N2 uptake at a relative pressure (p/p0) of 0.99 [43]. The volume of micropores (Vmicro ) was calculated from the t-plot method using Harkins-Jura master isotherm [44], and the volume of mesopores (Vmeso ) was calculated by Vmeso =Vt -Vmicro . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Coke evolution on catalyst Fig. 2 shows the TPO curves of the catalyst treated at various TOS in the catalytic pyrolysis of PE. The coke yields determined by the differential thermal gravimetry (DTG) peak areas are 0.8%, 2.4% and 6.3% of the catalyst mass at TOS = 1 h, 2 h and 4 h, respectively. The DTG peaks were deconvoluted into two Gaussian peaks, indicating two types of coke: coke I, peak temperatures at 400-433 °C; and coke II, peak temperatures at 464-488 °C. The low temperature coke (coke I) corresponds to the external coke with a less developed structure and high H/C ratio, while the high temperature coke (coke II) corresponds to the internal coke and is more condensed with a low H/C ratio [41]. With the deconvoluted DTG peaks, the yields and peak temperatures of the external and internal coke can be obtained as shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that the coke deposits on the external and internal surface of the catalyst simultaneously, but the external deposition is a little faster than internal deposition. The peak temperatures of external and internal coke increase with TOS, indicating the possible condensation of both external and internal coke with time. Fig. 4 shows the H/C ratio of the overall coke, i.e. the mixture of external and internal coke, since the ratio was determined by the elemental analysis (combustion analysis at 550 °C). The H/C is 0.72 at TOS = 1 h and increases to 1.10 at TOS = 2 h due to the faster deposition of the external coke (high H/C ratio) than internal coke (low H/C ratio) as shown in Fig.3. It is interesting to see that the H/C decreases to 0.91 as TOS increases to 4 h. Considering that the external deposition is faster than internal deposition, the decrease of H/C ratio indicate that the coke is condensing with time, which is supported by the increasing deconvoluted peak temperatures with TOS as shown in Fig. 3. The carbon species of the coke deposited on catalyst were characterized by 13C NMR as shown in Fig. 5 . The characteristic bands in the region of 10-50 and 100-170 were obtained, corresponding to the aliphatic and aromatic carbons of the coke, respectively [12]. The intensity of the bands becomes strong with the increase of TOS, indicating the increase of both aliphatic and aromatic carbons. To further investigate the coke structure, the 13C NMR signals were deconvoluted with multiple peaks as shown in Fig. 5. The carbon species were classified into 5 categories according to the literature [45–47], and the detailed parameters were listed in Table 1 . Based on the calibration method detailed in Fig. S2 and Table S1, the relative amount of each carbon species was approximated as shown in Table 1. It can be seen that the coke at TOS = 1 h contains no aliphatic carbons, possibly because the aliphatic coke concentration is too below to be detected as this sample shows significantly less coke than the others. The aromatic carbons are more than the aliphatic carbons in all the three samples, but the proportions of each aromatic carbon species are different. The condensation degrees, defined as the proportion of bridging ring junction carbons (species d) in total aromatic carbons (species c + d+e) [47], of the coke are 30.5%, 31.6% and 48.0% at TOS = 1 h, 2 h and 4 h, respectively. It has been found that the external coke deposits faster than internal coke. As TOS increases, the overall coke is supposed to be less condensed because the proportion of external coke grows. However, the condensation degrees show an increase with TOS. It is an evidence that not only the relative amounts of internal and external coke are changing, but also their chemical structures are condensing. To provide an intuitive description of coke, the average coke structures were described in Table 1 according to the carbon concentration. It should be pointed out that: (1) the structures are the average models but not the specific coke structures because the coke is a mixture of both external and internal coke, whose chemical structures are different; (2) the structure is just one of the possible candidates because the heterogeneous molecular structures of coke may include their isomers. The average coke structure, evolves from a tricyclic aromatic to a hexacyclic alkyl aromatic, indicate the coke evolution toward a more condensed level, as also evidenced by the UV-Vis spectra in Fig. 6 , which shows an obvious increase with TOS at 410 nm - corresponding to the 2-3 ring aromatics [41]. The sample at TOS = 4 h also shows a potential band at a high wavelength (near 550 nm), indicating a high aromaticity (> 4-membered rings) of the coke [12,41]. The carbon of the coke can also be characterized by FTIR as shown in Fig. 7 . Typical bands of hydrocarbon molecules are observed on two spectral regions: 2700-3100 cm-1 and 1300-1700 cm-1. The former is attributed to the C-H stretching modes of aliphatics (asymmetric and symmetric stretching) while the latter is attributed to the C-C stretching modes of poly-condensed aromatics, conjugated olefins, and some bending modes of aliphatics [12,48]. In Fig. 7, the bands at 2925 and 2851 cm-1 correspond to -CH2 (or -CH) group while that at 2961 cm-1 corresponds to -CH3 group. It can be seen that the coke at TOS = 1 h has few aliphatic carbons. When the TOS increases, the aliphatic structure starts to appear, which is accordant with the results shown in Fig. 5. The bands at 3050-3080 cm-1 (anti-symmetric olefinic -CH2 groups [12]) are absent, and no further peaks except 2925 and 2961 cm-1 are present at 2875-3000 cm-1 (symmetric -CH and -CH2 olefinic groups [12]), indicating that aliphatic side chains of the coke are saturated. The bands from 1450-1620 cm-1 are mainly attributed to the vibration of the aromatic structures. It is reported that the band near 1450 cm-1 (1460 cm-1 in Fig. 7) can be attributed to alkyl aromatics [48] or small coke precursor molecules with 2-3 aromatic rings [49,50]. The band at 1551 cm-1 is likely to be the polyaromatics [48]. The intensity of the band at 1460 and 1551 cm-1 becomes slightly strong with the increase of TOS due to the increase in both quantity and aromaticity of the coke. The band near 1620 cm-1 can be attributed to the double-bonds of the aromatic rings [12], which are present in all the three samples. The band near 1400 cm-1, which is present mainly at TOS = 2 h and 4 h, may be attributed to the -CH3 group substituted on the aromatic carbon of the coke [12]. 3.2 Catalytic activity on pyrolysis for oil The coke evolution influences the catalyst activity on the catalytic pyrolysis of PE. It can be seen in Fig. 8 that PE can be effectively cracked by the catalyst to form mainly liquid oil as well as some gaseous products, solid wax, and coke on catalyst. The increasing coke yields (based on the PE mass) with TOS - from 1.6% at TOS = 1 h to 2.4% and 3.2% at TOS = 2 h and 4 h, respectively - result in the decrease in oil and gas yields but an increase in wax yield, indicating the catalyst deactivation with coke evolution. The deactivation affects not only the product yields but also their compositions as shown in Fig. 9 . The condensable products at TOS = 1 h show a narrow carbon number distribution mainly from C7 to C14, which is accordant with the results that HY zeolite favors the oil production in gasoline range [27]. As TOS increases, the carbon number distribution of condensable products becomes wide and the maximum fraction shifts toward a higher carbon number. The oil quality becomes poor with TOS because the large molecular products in the oil fraction is more abundant at a longer TOS as the green zone in Fig. 9 shows. The yields of wax fraction become higher with the increase of TOS as the yellow zone in Fig. 9 shows. These phenomena indicate that the cracking ability of the Y-zeolite based catalyst decreases with coke evolution and promotes the formation of long carbon chain products. 3.3 Properties of the coked catalysts The decrease of the catalyst activity with coke evolution is mainly due to the changes in the acidity. Therefore, the NH3-TPD curves of the fresh and coked catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . Two main desorption regions were observed in the curves, indicating the presence of weak acid site (lower than 270 °C) and strong acid site (270-450 °C) on the Y-zeolite based catalyst [28]. When the coke evolves with TOS, the numbers of both weak and strong acid sites decrease, and the influence of coke on the acidity seems more obvious on strong acid site than on weak acid site. To better understand the relation between acidity and coke evolution, the acidities were plotted against coke yields as Fig. 11 shows. The acidities of the strong and weak acid sites were calculated by the multi-peak fitting method illustrated in Fig. S3 and Table S2. It is observed that the acidity of the strong acid sites decreases faster than that of the weak acid sites as the coke yields increase, because the oligomerization and condensation are favored to happen on strong acid sites as reported in the literature [18,51–53]. It is interesting to find that the decrease of acidities with coke yields becomes slow as the trend lines shows in Fig. 11 (comparison with linear trend was also made in Fig. S4, and the quality of fit is shown in Table S3). The decelerated trend is probably due to the fast deposition of external coke, which grows without the influence of the acid sites. Table 2 shows the BET surface areas and pore volumes of the fresh and coked catalysts. The BET surface areas decrease with TOS due to coke deposition. The proportion of micropore area in BET surface area decreases with TOS, indicating that the coke deposition is more pronounced in micropores. It can also be evidenced by the pore volumes, which show that the micropore volumes decrease faster than mesopore volumes. The results are not surprising because large pores always allow a better mass transfer and the consequent coke resistance than small pores [27]. 4 Conclusions The commercial Y-zeolite based catalyst used in the catalytic pyrolysis of PE for fuel oil suffers from coking problems. During the continuous feeding of PE in a two-stage fixed bed reactor, the coke amounts increase with TOS - from 0.8% of the catalyst mass at TOS = 1 h to 2.4% and 6.3% at TOS = 2 h and 4 h, respectively. External and internal coke is presented on catalyst according to the deconvoluted DTG peaks, and the former deposits faster than the latter. Results obtained from DTG peak temperature, H/C ratio, 13C NMR, UV-Vis and FTIR indicate the coke condensation with time. The average coke structure changes from a tricyclic aromatic to a hexacyclic alkyl aromatic as TOS increases from 1 h to 4 h. PE can be effectively converted to mainly liquid oil in gasoline range by the Y-zeolite based catalyst, but the coke evolution causes the catalyst deactivation, resulting in the decrease of the oil yields but the increase of wax yields as well as heavy oil concentration. Coke deposition is faster on strong acid sites than weak acid sites, and the fast external deposition leads to the slow decrease of acidities with coke yields. BET test results indicate the more pronounced coke deposition in micropores than the large pores. coredata.dc:description: Coke evolution on a Y-zeolite based catalyst and its influence on the active site and catalytic activity during catalytic pyrolysis of polyethylene for fuel oil were investigated. Results show that the coke evolution includes both quantity accumulation and structural condensation. The coke amounts increase from 0.8% at TOS = 1 h to 2.4% and 6.3% at TOS = 2 h and 4 h respectively, and the external coke deposits faster than the internal coke. Structural condensation is evidenced by DTG, H/C, 13C NMR, FTIR and UV-Vis results. The average coke model changes from a tricyclic aromatic to a hexacyclic alkyl aromatic as TOS increases from 1 h to 4 h. Coke evolution causes catalyst deactivation, resulting in the decrease of oil yields but increase of wax yields and heavy oil concentration. The strong acid sites and micropores favor the coke deposition, and fast external deposition leads to slow decrease of acidities with coke yields.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation of a Y-zeolite based catalyst with coke evolution during the catalytic pyrolysis of polyethylene for fuel oil
